stories.text:
It's no secret that the tech industry lends itself to operating in a way that can have negative impacts on the mental wellness of its workers. This industry has a ton of pressure around maintaining adherence to strict schedules and is very demanding of constant productivity. In my experience(as a neurodivergent person) there is also a fairly high presence of neurodivergent people drawn to working in the industry.

Do you feel like your neurodivergence is ever a boon in your job? Have you struggled with mental health while working in tech? Has a diagnosis and/or treatment helped? Do you have tips to share? And finally... Can Neurodiversity make us better hackers?
stories.title: Ask HN: Mental Disorder and Neurodiversity in Tech

stories.text:
With the US supreme court struggling to keep a consistent view of which constitutional rights really exist, perhaps it is time for the people to clarify what the constitution means (or what it should say).

I know that in the current political climate, getting the major parties to agree to anything seems impossible, let alone something as important as the foundational law of the whole country, but sometimes it takes a jolt to get a system out of a local minimum towards a lower energy state.

So, with historic understandings of the right to privacy and personal liberty seemingly under threat, an obvious focus for an amendment would be to enumerate some of the unenumerated rights that courts have acknowledged. However, in order to make the resultant set of rights acceptable to as many people as possible, there would have to be some compromises.

As a first approximation, then, consider the following principles that could form the basis for such an amendment:

* There is a federal right to privacy, which protects the people from intrusion into their private lives by the federal government.

* This does not preclude state governments from regulating private activities, where the state has a compelling interest and doesn't infringe on long-standing unenumerated rights.

* In particular, states can (within their jurisdiction) ban prostitution, regulate drug consumption, and define when life begins.

* However, states must recognize marriages that are recognized by other states, and cannot regulate acts in the bedroom of consenting adults (unless prostitution is involved).

Obviously this is an awkward set of compromises to make, and I don't claim that these are the exact set that should be adopted, just that there could be some give-and-take like this, leading to a deal being made where almost everyone walks away feeling like they benefited.

The reason why a conservative might agree to it is that allows their state to ban abortion, without the risk that the leaked SCOTUS decision ends up backfiring and undermining the Republicans' electoral chances (leading to Congress either passing the WHPA or packing the court), and it supports the principle of states' rights.

The reason why a liberal might agree to it is that they might not be able to rely on SCOTUS precedent on abortion any more, and by allowing states to preserve access to it they can still help women to obtain them for the cost of a bus ticket. They would also be able to properly legalize any drugs they thought were safe, and not have to worry about SCOTUS reversing other decisions about marriage or sexuality.

Moreover, though, I think everyone would benefit from turning down the temperature and lowering the stakes of presidential and congressional elections. Rather than having two big (to fail) parties locked into an eternal war over wedge issues, it would make these become local issues that could be dealt with on a state by state basis. As an extra safety valve, though, I would propose that the amendment contains a sunset clause, saying that it expires after 50 years, at which point the culture will have moved on and a new set of compromises might be needed.
